Know that the method in disciplining children is among the most important and most emphasized matters, and children are a trust (Amanah) upon their parents. Their pure heart (Qalb) is a precious, simple jewel, empty of every engraving and image, and it is receptive to everything that is engraved upon it and inclined to everything it is directed toward. If he is accustomed to good and taught it, he grows up upon it and becomes fortunate in this world and the Hereafter, and his father and every teacher and educator share in his reward. But if he is accustomed to evil and neglected like animals, he becomes wretched and perishes, and the burden is upon the neck of the one responsible for him and his guardian. And Allah the Exalted has said: "O you who have believed, protect yourselves and your families from a Fire (Nar) whose fuel is people and stones, over which are [appointed] angels, harsh and severe; they do not disobey Allah in what He commands them but do what they are commanded." And whatever the father does to protect him from the fire of this world, it is more appropriate to protect him from the Fire (Nar) of the Hereafter. And his protection is by disciplining him, refining him, teaching him the beauties of character, protecting him from bad companions, not accustoming him to luxury, and not making adornment and comfort beloved to him, lest he waste his life seeking them when he grows up and thus perish eternally. Rather, he should be monitored from the very beginning, so that only a religious woman who eats lawful (Halal) food is employed in his nursing and breastfeeding, for the milk obtained from unlawful (Haram) sources has no blessing (Barakah) in it. If the child's growth occurs upon it, his clay is kneaded from the impure, and his nature inclines toward what corresponds to impurities.

And whenever she learns what is from the obligations upon her, then she has no right to go out to a gathering of remembrance (Dhikr) nor to learn excellence except with his permission.
